alert.note: Alert for Tillamook (Oregon) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Portland (Northwest Oregon and Southwest Washington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued December 05 at 4:37AM PST until December 06 at 1:06AM PST by NWS Portland
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Portland OR has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Oregon... Wilson River near Tillamook affecting Tillamook County. Nehalem River near Foss affecting Clatsop and Tillamook Counties. Siletz River at Siletz affecting Lincoln County. Trask River near Tillamook affecting Tillamook County. ...Observed flooding changed from Minor to Major severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Washington... Grays River at Covered Bridge near Rosburg affecting Wahkiakum County. .Widespread rain has caused sudden rises along area rivers and feeding streams. Rain will persist through Wednesday. For the Nw Oregon / Sw Washington Coast...including Willapa, Naselle, Vernonia, Covered Bridge near Rosburg, Foss, Tillamook, Tillamook, Beaver, Siletz, Tidewater, Mapleton...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL JUST AFTER MIDNIGHT TONIGHT... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Wilson River near Tillamook. * WHEN...Until just after midnight tonight. * IMPACTS...Above 14.0 feet, widespread lowland and dairy land flooding begins. Sloughs north of the city, mainly Dougherty, begin to overflow. Minor flooding begins in the business district north of Tillamook and along Hwy 101, particularly during high tide. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:30 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 11.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 10.5 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage early this morning to 13.7 feet late this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage this evening to 6.5 feet early Saturday morning. It will rise to 7.3 feet early Sunday morning. It will then fall to 5.9 feet Wednesday, December 13. It will then rise again but remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this afternoon at 500 PM PST.
